member.summary: An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The prompt should match the audio language.

member.summary: The format of the transcript output, in one of these options: json, text, srt, verbose_json, or vtt.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.Audio.Transcription.TranscriptionRequest.Temperature
member.summary: The sampling temperature, between 0 and 1. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic. If set to 0, the model will use log probability to automatically increase the temperature until certain thresholds are hit.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.Audio.Transcription.TranscriptionRequest.Language
member.summary: The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in ISO-639-1 format will improve accuracy and latency.

member.summary: The messages to generate chat completions for, in the chat format.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.Temperature
member.summary:
What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks.
Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer.
We generally recommend altering this or top_p but not both.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.TopP
member.summary:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass.
So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.
We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.NumberOfChoicesPerMessage
member.summary:
How many completions to generate for each prompt.
Note: Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota.
Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for max_tokens and stop.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.Stream
member.summary:
Whether to stream back partial progress.
If set, tokens will be sent as data-only server-sent events as they become available, with the stream terminated by a data: [DONE] message.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.StopSequences
member.summary:
Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens.
The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.StopSequence
member.summary: The stop sequence where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence. For convenience, if you are only requesting a single stop sequence, set it here

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.MaxTokens
member.summary:
The maximum number of tokens to generate in the completion.
The token count of your prompt plus max_tokens cannot exceed the model's context length. Most models have a context length of 2048 tokens (except for the newest models, which support 4096).

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.PresencePenalty
member.summary: Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics. See more information about frequency and presence penalties.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.FrequencyPenalty
member.summary:
Number between -2.0 and 2.0.
Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.
See more information about frequency and presence penalties.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.ChatCompletions.ChatCompletionRequest.LogitBias
member.summary:
Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion.
Accepts a json object that maps tokens(specified by their token ID in the GPT tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100.
You can use this tokenizer tool (which works for both GPT-2 and GPT-3) to convert text to token IDs.
Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling.
The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token.
As an example, you can pass
to prevent the <|endoftext|> token from being generated.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: if set to true [compute classification metrics].

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.TrainingFileId
member.summary:
The ID of an uploaded file that contains training data.
See upload file for how to upload a file.
Your dataset must be formatted as a JSONL file, where each training example is a JSON object with the keys "prompt" and "completion".
Additionally, you must upload your file with the purpose fine-tune.
See the fine-tuning guide for more details.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.ValidationFileId
member.summary:
The ID of an uploaded file that contains validation data.
If you provide this file, the data is used to generate validation metrics periodically during fine-tuning.
These metrics can be viewed in the fine-tuning results file .
Your train and validation data should be mutually exclusive.
Your dataset must be formatted as a JSONL file, where each training example is a JSON object with the keys "prompt" and "completion".
Additionally, you must upload your file with the purpose fine-tune.
See the fine-tuning guide for more details.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.Model
member.summary:
The name of the base model to fine-tune.You can select one of "ada", "babbage", "curie", "davinci", or a fine-tuned model created after 2022-04-21.
To learn more about these models, see the Models documentation.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.Epochs
member.summary:
The number of epochs to train the model for.
An epoch refers to one full cycle through the training dataset.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.BatchSize
member.summary:
The batch size to use for training.
The batch size is the number of training examples used to train a single forward and backward pass.
By default, the batch size will be dynamically configured to be ~0.2% of the number of examples in the training set, capped at 256 - in general, we've found that larger batch sizes tend to work better for larger datasets.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.LearningRateMultiplier
member.summary:
The learning rate multiplier to use for training.
The fine-tuning learning rate is the original learning rate used for pretraining multiplied by this value.
By default, the learning rate multiplier is the 0.05, 0.1, or 0.2 depending on final batch_size (larger learning rates tend to perform better with larger batch sizes). We recommend experimenting with values in the range 0.02 to 0.2 to see what produces the best results.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.PromptLossWeight
member.summary:
The weight to use for loss on the prompt tokens.
This controls how much the model tries to learn to generate the prompt (as compared to the completion which always has a weight of 1.0), and can add a stabilizing effect to training when completions are short.
If prompts are extremely long (relative to completions), it may make sense to reduce this weight so as to avoid over-prioritizing learning the prompt.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.ComputeClassificationMetrics
member.summary:
If set, we calculate classification-specific metrics such as accuracy and F-1 score using the validation set at the end of every epoch. These metrics can be viewed in the results file.
In order to compute classification metrics, you must provide a validation_file.
Additionally, you must specify classification_n_classes for multiclass classification or classification_positive_class for binary classification

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.ClassificationNClasses
member.summary:
The number of classes in a classification task.
This parameter is required for multiclass classification.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.ClassificationPositiveClasses
member.summary:
The positive class in binary classification.
This parameter is needed to generate precision, recall, and F1 metrics when doing binary classification.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.ClassificationBetas
member.summary:
If this is provided, we calculate F-beta scores at the specified beta values.
The F-beta score is a generalization of F-1 score. This is only used for binary classification.
With a beta of 1 (i.e. the F-1 score), precision and recall are given the same weight.
A larger beta score puts more weight on recall and less on precision.
A smaller beta score puts more weight on precision and less on recall.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.FineTunes.FineTuneCreateRequest.Suffix
member.summary:
A string of up to 40 characters that will be added to your fine-tuned model name.
For example, a suffix of "custom-model-name" would produce a model name like

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.Models.Model.Davinci
member.summary:
The most powerful, largest engine available, although the speed is quite slow.
Good at: Complex intent, cause and effect, summarization for audience https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-3

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.Models.Model.Curie
member.summary:
The 2nd most powerful engine, a bit faster than , and a bit faster.
Good at: Language translation, complex classification, text sentiment, summarization. https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-3

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.Models.Model.Babbage
member.summary:
The 2nd fastest engine, a bit more powerful than , and a bit slower.
Good at: Moderate classification, semantic search classification https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-3

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.Models.Model.Ada
member.summary:
The smallest, fastest engine available, although the quality of results may be poor.
Good at: Parsing text, simple classification, address correction, keywords https://platform.openai.com/docs/models/gpt-3

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.Moderations.ModerationRequest.Model
member.summary:
Two content moderations models are available: text-moderation-stable and text-moderation-latest.
The default is text-moderation-latest which will be automatically upgraded over time.
This ensures you are always using our most accurate model.
If you use text-moderation-stable, we will provide advanced notice before updating the model.
Accuracy of text-moderation-stable may be slightly lower than for text-moderation-latest.

member.summary: Mostly matches the parameters in the OpenAI docs, although some have been renames or expanded into single/multiple properties for ease of use.

member.name: M:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.#ctor(Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest)
member.summary: Creates a new , inheriting any parameters set in .
Creates a new with the specified parameters
member.param: ID of the model to use. You can use the List models API to see all of your available models, or see our Model overview for descriptions of them.
The suffix that comes after a completion of inserted text.
How many tokens to complete to. Can return fewer if a stop sequence is hit.

What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks. Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.

An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered. It is generally recommend to use this or but not both.
How many different choices to request for each prompt.
The scale of the penalty applied if a token is already present at all. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.
The scale of the penalty for how often a token is used. Should generally be between 0 and 1, although negative numbers are allowed to encourage token reuse.

Include the log probabilities on the logProbabilities most likely tokens, which can be found in Completions -> . So for example, if logprobs is 10, the API will return a list of the 10 most likely tokens. If logprobs is supplied, the API will always return the logprob of the sampled token, so there may be up to logprobs+1 elements in the response.
Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion.
One or more sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.
A dictionary of logit bias to influence the probability of generating a token.
Returns the top bestOf results based on the best probability.
A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.Model
member.summary: ID of the model to use.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.Prompts
member.summary: The prompt(s) to generate completions for, encoded as a string, array of strings, array of tokens, or array of token arrays.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.Prompt
member.summary: For convenience, if you are only requesting a single prompt, set it here

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.Suffix
member.summary: The suffix that comes after a completion of inserted text.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.MaxTokens
member.summary:
The maximum number of tokens to generate in the completion.
The token count of your prompt plus max_tokens cannot exceed the model's context length. Most models have a context length of 2048 tokens (except for the newest models, which support 4096).

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.Temperature
member.summary:
What sampling temperature to use. Higher values means the model will take more risks.
Try 0.9 for more creative applications, and 0 (argmax sampling) for ones with a well-defined answer.
We generally recommend altering this or top_p but not both.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.TopP
member.summary:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass.
So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.
We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.PresencePenalty
member.summary: Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.FrequencyPenalty
member.summary:
Number between -2.0 and 2.0.
Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.
See more information about frequency and presence penalties.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.NumberOfChoicesPerPrompt
member.summary:
How many completions to generate for each prompt.
Note: Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota.
Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for max_tokens and stop.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.Stream
member.summary:
Whether to stream back partial progress.
If set, tokens will be sent as data-only server-sent events as they become available, with the stream terminated by a data: [DONE] message.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.LogProbabilities
member.summary:
Include the log probabilities on the logprobs most likely tokens, as well the chosen tokens.
For example, if logprobs is 5, the API will return a list of the 5 most likely tokens.
The API will always return the logprob of the sampled token, so there may be up to logprobs+1 elements in the response.
The maximum value for logprobs is 5. If you need more than this, please contact us through our Help center and describe your use case.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.Echo
member.summary: Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.StopSequences
member.summary:
Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens.
The returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.StopSequence
member.summary: The stop sequence where the API will stop generating further tokens. The returned text will not contain the stop sequence. For convenience, if you are only requesting a single stop sequence, set it here

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.LogitBias
member.summary:
Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion.
Accepts a json object that maps tokens(specified by their token ID in the GPT tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100.
You can use this tokenizer tool (which works for both GPT-2 and GPT-3) to convert text to token IDs.
Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling.
The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token.
As an example, you can pass
to prevent the <|endoftext|> token from being generated.

member.name: P:Forge.OpenAI.Models.TextCompletions.TextCompletionRequest.BestOf
member.summary:
Generates best_of completions server-side and returns the "best" (the one with the highest log probability per token).
Results cannot be streamed.
When used with n, best_of controls the number of candidate completions and n specifies how many to return best_of must be greater than n.
Note: Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota.
Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for max_tokens and stop.

member.summary: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse. Learn more.

and can also return the probabilities of alternative tokens at each position.
